description: Like 'a' in 'taco'. An open, central vowel, always the same sound.
Like 'e' in 'café'. A front vowel, shorter and tenser than English 'ay'.
Like 'ee' in 'see'. A high, front vowel, shorter and tenser than in English.
Like 'o' in 'tango'. A back, rounded vowel, shorter and tenser than English 'oh'.
Like 'oo' in 'food'. A high, back, tightly rounded vowel.
Like English 'p' but with less puff of air. A voiceless sound from the lips.
At start of word, like English 'b'. Between vowels, a softer 'v' sound [β].
Like English 't', but the tongue touches the back of the teeth, not the ridge behind them.
At start of word, like English 'd'. Between vowels, a soft 'th' [ð] like in 'this'.
Like English 'k' in 'key'. A hard, voiceless sound from the back of the tongue (c, qu).
At start of word, a hard 'g' like in 'go'. Between vowels, a soft, breathy sound [ɣ].
Exactly like 'ch' in English 'church'.
Exactly like 'f' in English 'fan'.
Like English 's' in 'sun'. (Used for s, c, and z in Latin America).
A rough, scraping sound from the back of the throat, like 'ch' in Scottish 'loch'. (j, g).
Exactly like 'm' in English 'man'.
Exactly like 'n' in English 'nose'.
Like the 'ny' in English 'canyon'. The 'ñ' sound.
Like English 'l' but with the tongue tip higher and more forward, against the teeth.
The 'y' or 'll' sound. Like 'y' in 'yes', but can be stronger, almost like 'j' in 'jam'.
The 'single r' tap. A very quick flap of the tongue against the roof of the mouth. Like the 't' in American English 'water'.
The 'rolled rr' trill. Multiple quick taps of the tongue against the roof of the mouth.
A gliding sound like 'w' in English 'we', often appears as 'hu' or in diphthongs.
